choices.F: Partition key columns cannot be dropped.
choices.B: A column that is set to UNUSED still counts towards the limit of 1000 columns per table.
choices.E: An UNUSED column's space is reclaimed automatically when the block containing that column is next queried.
choices.C: A DROP COLUMN command can be rolled back.
choices.D: A primary key column referenced by another column as a foreign key can be dropped if using the CASCADE option.
choices.A: An UNUSED column's space is reclaimed automatically when the row containing that column is next queried.

discussion.content:
Correct answers are B , D and F 
see : https://dbaclass.com/article/ora-12984-cannot-drop-partitioning-column/#google_vignette

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about aggregate functions?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A. Aggregate functions can be nested to any number of levels. -> Can be nested upto one level only.
B. The AVG function implicitly converts NULLS to zero. -> AVG function ignores NULLS.
C. The MAX and MIN functions can be used on columns with character data types. -> True
D. Aggregate functions can be used in any clause of a SELECT statement. -> It can't be used with where clause.

Selected Answer: C
tested on a sample data

choices.B: The AVG function implicitly converts NULLS to zero.
choices.D: Aggregate functions can be used in any clause of a SELECT statement.
choices.A: Aggregate functions can be nested to any number of levels.
choices.C: The MAX and MIN functions can be used on columns with character data types.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACF
A. Multitable INSERT statements can insert each computed row into more than one table. This is achieved by specifying multiple INTO clauses in the INSERT statement, each corresponding to a different table. Here's an example:
INSERT ALL INTO table1 (column1, column2) VALUES (value1, value2) INTO table2 (column3, column4) VALUES (value3, value4) SELECT * FROM source_table;
In this example, the computed rows from the source_table are inserted into both table1 and table2.
C. Multitable INSERT statements can be performed on external tables using SQL*Loader. External tables allow you to access data in external files as if it were in a regular database table. Here's an example:
INSERT ALL INTO table1 (column1, column2) VALUES (value1, value2) INTO table2 (column3, column4) VALUES (value3, value4) SELECT * FROM external_table;
In this example, the data from the external_table is inserted into both table1 and table2.
F. Multitable INSERT statements can be performed on relational tables. Relational tables

questions.question_text: Which three are true about multitable INSERT statements? (Choose three.)

choices.E: They can be performed only by using a subquery.
choices.F: They can be performed on relational tables.
choices.D: They can be performed on views.
choices.A: They can insert each computed row into more than one table.
choices.C: They can be performed on external tables using SQL*Loader.
choices.B: They can be performed on remote tables.

discussion.content: C is not correct. if no row is returned, it will not throw an error. DEF is ok

choices.A: They must be placed on the left side of the comparison operator or condition.
choices.C: They must return a row to prevent errors in the SQL statement.
choices.E: They can be used in the HAVING clause.
choices.F: They can be used in the WHERE clause.
choices.D: A SQL statement may have multiple single row subquery blocks.
choices.B: They must be placed on the right side of the comparison operator or condition.
